channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Saudis Announce Halt to Yemen Bombing Campaign
item.description: The Defense Ministry said the objectives in its bombing of Yemen’s Iran-backed Houthi rebels, which began March 26, had been achieved.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A Saudi soldier fired a mortar shell toward Houthi rebels in Yemen on Tuesday.

item.title: Israel Adds Name of Palestinian Teenager Who Was Abducted and Killed to Memorial
item.description: The addition of Muhammad Abu Khdeir’s name to the state’s memorial to victims of hostile acts drew criticism from his father and an Israeli activist group.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: As Athens Runs Short of Cash, Greece and Gazprom Chief Hold Talks
item.description: The meeting came amid speculation on a possible multibillion-dollar gas pipeline deal by Athens and Moscow, which could provide Greece needed money.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Aleksei B. Miller, center, the Gazprom chief executive, meeting on Tuesday with Alexis Tsipras, left, Greece's prime minister, and Panagiotis Lafazanis, the country's energy minister.

item.title: South African Army Deployed in Areas Hit by Anti-Immigrant Violence
item.description: The government has faced criticism that it responded too slowly to attacks that have claimed seven lives.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: Men suspected of killing a Mozambican immigrant were arraigned in Johannesburg on Tuesday.

item.title: Captain of Migrant Boat Hit Rescue Ship, Prosecutors Say
item.description: The captain, identified on Tuesday by prosecutors in Sicily as Mohammed Ali Malek, 27, was arrested on suspicion of multiple homicide.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Migrants who survived a boat sinking over the weekend arrived at the Sicilian port city of Catania early on Tuesday.

item.title: Hundreds of Chinese Cities Don’t Meet Air Standards, Report Finds
item.description: Interior provinces had the most polluted cities during those months, according to a study released by Greenpeace East Asia.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Morning exercises on a polluted day in March in Jiaozuo, Henan Province, China.

item.title: Co-Pilot’s Coffee Spill Blamed in Plunge of Serbian President’s Plane
item.description: In trying to clean up the spill, the co-pilot accidentally activated an instrument that led to a brief engine shutdown, investigators said.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: Russian Workers Take Aim at Putin as Economy Exacts Its Toll
item.description: Subdued for a time by a surge in national pride after the annexation of Crimea, discontent over unpaid wages and forced vacations has generated a wave of labor actions.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: The Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, in Moscow last week. Workers across Russia are starting to protest against unpaid wages and go on strike, in the first nationwide backlash against Mr. Putin's economic policies.

item.title: Egyptian Court Sentences Mohamed Morsi to 20 Years in Prison
item.description: Mr. Morsi, the deposed president, was sentenced after being convicted of charges stemming from a night of bloody street fighting between his supporters and opponents in 2012.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MERNA THOMAS
item.media:description: Mohamed Morsi, Egypt's ousted Islamist president, inside a makeshift courtroom in Cairo on Tuesday.

item.title: Russian Premier Says Annexation of Crimea Was Worth Sanctions Fallout
item.description: Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev’s estimated that Russia had lost $26.8 billion but that the economic pressure was “the price we have to pay for our position.”
item.dc:creator: ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia delivered a speech to lawmakers in Moscow on Tuesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: What a Difference a Decade Makes: Xinjiang Film Emerges From the Past
item.description: Filmed across the region in 2002 before it became gripped by ethnic tension and violence, the award-winning “Poet on a Business Trip” traces a journey marked by sensual pleasure and exhaustion.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: An image from "Poet on a Business Trip," in which a poet sends himself on a journey across the western region of Xinjiang. The movie was released in black and white because the colors had deteriorated since it was filmed in 2002.

item.title: Eritrea and North Korea Are World’s Most Censored Countries, Advocacy Group Says
item.description: The list by the Committee to Protect Journalists also counts Azerbaijan, China, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Myanmar and Vietnam as among the top jailers of journalists.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Lens Blog: Scenes From the Ebola Crisis Earn Photography Pulitzer
item.description: Daniel Berehulak’s coverage of the Ebola crisis in West Africa for The New York Times earned him the Pulitzer Prize for feature photography.
item.dc:creator: JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:description: New York Times employees celebrate Daniel Berehulak, center, who was awarded a Pulitzer in the Feature Photography category. The newspaper won three Pulitzer prizes.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Study Tracks Accelerated Pace and Growing Pains of China’s Urbanization
item.description: The report looks at several facets of a sweeping government-led effort to transform the country from a once-predominantly rural economy to a land of modern city dwellers.
item.category: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER
item.media:description: Commuters jamming into a Beijing subway car. A new report says that China has more cities with populations exceeding 10 million than government figures suggest.

item.title: Iran Sees Yemen Ceasefire in Coming Hours
item.description: Iran’s deputy foreign minister said he was optimistic that a ceasefire in Yemen would be announced later on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Trial of Former Auschwitz Guard, 93, Opens in Germany
item.description: Oskar Gröning is charged with complicity in the murder of 300,000 mostly Hungarian Jewish prisoners at the Nazi death camp in 1944.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Oskar Gröning, former SS guard at Auschwitz-Birkenau, arrived for the opening of his trial in Lüneburg, Germany, on Tuesday.

item.title: India Says It Seized Heroin Believed to Be Worth Nearly $100 Million From Boat
item.description: The cache, which the Indian Navy said weighed about 500 pounds, was found aboard a Pakistani vessel; eight Pakistanis were detained.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Our Man in Tehran - Episode 5: An Eye for an Eye
item.description: After Ameneh Bahrami was blinded and disfigured by a scorned suitor who poured acid on her face, she fought to punish her attacker in kind.
item.dc:creator: As told to THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong University Official Backtracks on Mandatory China Visits
item.description: Ian Holliday, a vice president of the university and a professor of politic science, said on Friday that students who do not wish to go to mainland China should not study at the university, drawing criticism from students who have misgivings about China’s growing influence on the city.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG

item.title: Shinzo Abe, Japanese Premier, Sends Gift to Contentious Yasukuni Shrine
item.description: The gesture could anger China and South Korea, which see the Yasukuni Shrine as a symbol of Japan’s inability to fully come to terms with its wartime past.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: A wooden sign marks the offering, a potted evergreen shrub, sent to the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo on Tuesday by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. The shrine commemorates Japan’s war dead, including war criminals.
